titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Le Bayou Records
titlestmt.author: Dick Dickerson, Meghan McCain

titlepage.titleproper: Guide to the Le Bayou Records 1934/1964

did.head: Overview of the Collection

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

did.abstract: This collection contains papers related to the publication of Le Bayou and includes subscription information, correspondence, and the submissions of both published and unpublished authors. It also includes the papers of Le Quartier Latin, the French Club of the University of Houston, and its publication Le Feuille de Chou.

bioghist.head: Historical Note:
bioghist.p: Born at Le Havre in Normandy, in 1892, Jules Vern came to this country in 1930. Jules Vern was called in 1934 to the University of Houston to occupy a chair of professor of French; he organized the study of French so it would be a pleasure for his students to learn this language. When the Cullen Building was opened, he decorated his vast classroom with oil paintings, glass closets containing collections of rare objects, and shelves holding documentary books and foreign magazines. Soon his department was outstanding. He created a club, Le Quartier Latin, and a newspaper that he humorously called Le Feuille de Chou, written and published by his students.

With great success, he had previously founded Le Petit Théâtre Français de Houston, where many of the plays were his own and where French speaking Houstonians, professors of French, including the founder, and students performed. The French Government recognized his efforts in awarding him the decoration Officier d’Académie.

But the great achievement of his life has been the creations of Le Bayou. Jules Vern had the ambitious idea to publish a French magazine in Houston, a magazine in which would be found novels, short stories, essays, critiques, folklore, legends, and poetry concerning France and the South of the United States. In spite of financial difficulties, his tremendous will and perseverance brought success, and Le Bayou was born. In the following years, Le Bayou became known the world over, and was praised by the most prominent writers, not only of France, but of all the French-speaking countries. In 1946, the Academie Française granted to this magazine Le Prix de la Langue Française and a medal engraved with its name. Later, Jules A. Vern received coveted decoration of Officier de l’Instruction Publique as a reward for his literary achievements.

controlaccess.p: This Collection is indexed under the following controlled access subject terms.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use:
userestrict.p: Special Collections owns the physical items in our collections, but copyright normally belongs to the creator of the materials or their heirs. The researcher has full responsibility for determining copyright status, obtaining permission to publish from copyright holders, and abiding by current copyright laws when publishing or displaying copies of Special Collections material in print or electronic form. For more information, consult the appropriate librarian. Reproduction decisions will be made by Special Collections staff on a case-by-case basis.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Information of acquisition method not available.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: Le Bayou Records. Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

scopecontent.p: The Le Bayou collection consists of 20 boxes and is organized into 11 series: Administration, Le Quartier Latin, Correspondence, Submissions, Subscriptions, Le Petit Théâtre Français, Livre d’Or, and Journals, Artistic Stamps, Ledgers, and Photographic Materials. This collection contains papers related to the publication of Le Bayou and includes subscription information, correspondence, and the submissions of both published and unpublished authors. It also includes the papers of Le Quartier Latin, the French Club of the University of Houston, and its publication Le Feuille de Chou. Materials in the Collection date from 1934-1964, and much of it is in the French language.

For preservation and access reasons the collection has been re-boxed and re-foldered. New folder titles conform, as closely as possible, to original folder titles, except when the original was obviously incomplete, incorrect, or confusing. Original folder and item order has been maintained whenever possible. Exceptions were made when folders were obviously misfiled or when no order was apparent.

Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries has in its collection the original Le Bayou, under the call number AP21. B25. The bound volumes begin in 1936, with volume 1, and end with volume 95, in 1963.
This series consists of one box of Le Bayou’s administrative files, and includes documents that reflect the business aspect of an active international literary journal.

This subseries consists of 32 folders of general business concerns, such as advertising, financial documents, correspondence models, copyright, printing, and publicity. This subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

did.unittitle: Postal Life and Casualty Insurance; Kansas
Whitehead Sales and Supply Company; Houston

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 25 folders, mainly correspondence, that pertains to the organization Friends of Le Bayou. This organization was created to ensure that funds could be donated by interested persons and organizations for the continued financial support of this literary magazine. This subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

did.unittitle: Arnold, Mr. and Mrs. Isaac; Houston
de Menil; Mr. and Mrs. Jean; Houston
French Embassy, Cultural Division; New York
Friends of Le Bayou; Financial Information
Johnson, Mr. and Mrs. Elliott A.; Houston
Palen, Pierre; Consul à Houston, Texas

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 7 folders of materials that relate to Le Bayou’s Campagne de Fonds, a yearly fundraising gathering that took place from 1945 to 1953. This subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

This series consists of 44 folders of materials that relate to Le Quartier Latin, the French club of the University of Houston. It includes general club administrative information, correspondence (organized by date), La Feuille de Chou, its literary newsletter, fundraising events, and relating to exchanges with other magazines. This series is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

This subseries consists of 18 folders of materials that document the general organization of Le Quartier Latin, such as officer positions and the accompanying duties, membership lists, and financial information. This subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

did.unittitle: La Classe: La Révolution Littérature et Politique du XIX

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 8 correspondence folders organized by date. It contains correspondence from individuals, other journals, and organizations. This subseries is organized by date.
This subseries consists of copies of La Feuille de Chou, the newsletter of Le Quartier Latin. It consists of 8 folders organized by date.
This subseries consists of 7 folders of material that relates to several events that were held as fundraisers for the club, in its early years. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of one folder that contains documents relating to the exchange of La Feuille de Chou with other journals and magazines.

This series consists of about two boxes of correspondence, both personal and business. Correspondents of note include E.E. Oberholtzer, the founding president of the University of Houston. This series is organized alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of roughly 3 boxes of material that was submitted for publication in Le Bayou, from its inception to when it stopped publication in 1963. These folders include fiction, poetry, essays, and book reviews, and many of their authors submitted material for many years. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of material submitted for publication in Le Bayou, from its inception to when it stopped publication in 1963. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of three boxes of documents relating to subscriptions, as well as an index card file. It includes general subscriptions, gift subscriptions, individual subscriptions, organizations, and universities. It also includes the materials that contain information concerning the exchange of Le Bayou with other publications, and the orders made by subscription companies. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date. The index card file is at the end.

This subseries consists of 6 folders that relate to subscriptions for Le Bayou from 1938 to 1962. There is also material relating to orders for Ballades de Mon Bayou. It is arranged alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of one folder that contains gift subscription orders for Le Bayou from 1950 to 1955.
This subseries consists of 172 folders that contain subscription information for individual subscribers, for Le Bayou from 1941 to 1963. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

did.unittitle: Allard, Wilfred P.; United States Embassy, Paris; gift subscription

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of roughly 1 and a half boxes of materials relating to subscriptions for Le Bayou by bookstores, libraries, universities, and other kinds of organizations. It is arranged alphabetically, and then by date.

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 9 folders that contain materials that relates to subscription companies. Some individuals, universities, and organizations ordered their subscriptions through services that provided a large selection, rather than directly ordering from Le Bayou. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

did.unittitle: Bay State Periodical Service; Boston, Massachusetts
F.W. Faxon and Company; Boston, Massachusetts

scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains subscription information in the form of an index card file. It includes both the subscription information of individual people and organizations. This series is organized alphabetically.

This series consists of 10 folders that contain materials that relate to Le Petit Théâtre Français, including office documents, and copies of its publication La Gazette. Le Petit Théâtre Français was a French theater organization started by Jules Vern. This subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

did.unittitle: Le Petit Théâtre Français de Houston - La Gazette du Petit Théâtre, no.15
Le Petit Théâtre Français de Houston - La Gazette du Petit Théâtre, no.19

Le Petit Théâtre Français de Houston - La Gazette du Petit Théâtre, no.32

scopecontent.p: This series consists of 12 folders that contain original and duplicate copies of a scrapbook of clippings relating to Le Bayou and its publicity, from 1950 to 1959. For each original copy, which is organized by date, there is a duplicate copy. This series is organized by date.
This series consists of 2 subseries that consist of Éditions du Bayou and Journals Received. Each subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

This subseries consists of 16 folders that consist of Éditions de Bayou, a publication series that published small books of poetry, and smaller notebook versions of Le Bayou. This series is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

did.unittitle: Ballades de Mon Bayou - Sulver, Jean
En Marge des Saisons: Poèmes - Robert, Michel
Le Bayou - Tables of Contents nos.40-80

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 11 folders containing journals that Le Bayou either received in exchange from other publications, or were sent in hopes of such an exchange. This series is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

scopecontent.p: This series contains two small boxes of handcarved rubber stamps used in the production of Le Bayou.
This series contains two ledgers of financial information and one receipt book. This series is organized alphabetically, and then by date.

This series contains photographs of members of the Le Bayou staff and includes formal portraits of its founder, Jules Verne. It also contains two photo albums and one scrapbook with photographs of the Le Bayou staff at work and at play. This series is organized by date.
